lost this shawl—the prisoner came to me—I charged her with having stolen it—she denied it—I said it was no use to deny it, for I had found out where it was pledged in her name—I had been to Putney and seen it—I did not say it would be better for her to tell.
MARY ANN GOWER . This is my husband's shawl—I saw it safe at home on the 20th of May.
GEORGE SPENCER . I am a pawnbroker. I produce this shawl, which I took in of Stowell—she was alone when she pledged it—the bill against her was thrown out—this is the duplicate I gave of it.

JOHN CANNON (police-constable V 201.) I produce this duplicate, which I found at Stowell's house—I took the prisoner for taking the shawl—she asked me to allow her to dress, which I did—I sat down in the room—she said, "In taking this shawl I have added more to my misfortune."

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Is this your writing to this deposition? A. Yes; I was asked if it was correct, and I said it was—(read—" It only added to her misfortune in having anything to do with the shawl")—she said it added to her misfortune in taking the shawl.

HENRY GOWER
re-examined. Q. Did you in any way tell her that it would be better for her, or for her advantage, if she would tell you the truth and confess? A. No.

Cross-examined. Q. Will you take your oath you did not say it would be better she should tell you who took it, as you had found out where it was pledged, and in her name? A. Some of those words I did not—I said it was no use to deny it, I had found out where it was pledged.
NOT GUILTY .

1798.
JOSEPH CANNON and
DANIEL GARRARD were indicted for
unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.
MESSRS. CHAMBERS and SCRIVEN conducted the Prosecution.

CHRISTOPHER JOHN HILDYARD , draper, Kennington-cross. Between twelve and one o'clock on the 23rd of May, Cannon came into my shop, and asked if I could give him change for a sovereign—I said "Yes"—I tendered him 10s. in silver, and a half-sovereign—Garrard then came in, and Cannon said to him, "Here is the money I owe you, John," offerring him the half-sovereign—he said, "I would rather have silver," then Cannon asked if I could give them silver—I said, not unless he took all sixpences, which he did chiefly, and I received a counterfeit half-sovereign from one of the prisoners—I could not say which, because the money was laid on the counter—it is our custom to weigh gold—I could not speak to having weighed the half-sovereign I gave them myself—I put the half sovereign they gave me into my pocket, and passed it away to my sister—I saw her give it to the policeman.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did you know the prisoners at all? A. No, I never saw them to my knowledge—they were not in my shop many minutes—I know them—they were dressed precisely the same when I saw them again, except Cannon not having the pins in his stock, and a silver-headed cane.
MR. SCRIVEN. Q. When did the officer come into your shop? A. In a minute or two—I have not the slightest doubt that the prisoners are the persons.

ANGELINA FLETCHER HILDYARD . I am sister of Christopher Hildyard. I received a half sovereign from my brother on the 23rd of May—I put it in my purse—there was nothing else there but a few shillings—I did not keep it there very long—I brought my purse down, and gave the half-sovereign to the policeman.

CHARLES GREAVES , assistant to Mr. Dixon, linendraper, Blackfriars-road. On the 22nd of May, Cannon came for change for a sovereign—Gar
rard stood just outside the door—I gave Cannon four half-crowns, the rest in shillings and sixpences—he said he would rather have a half-sovereign—I gave him one, and took away the four half-crowns—I took the half-sovereign from the desk—there was no other in the place where I took it from—I had weighed it, and it was full weight—I had examined it to see whether it was a good one—after I had handed the half-sovereign to Cannon, he called in Garrard, and said he believed he owed him a half-sovereign—Garrard said he would rather have silver, and Garrard handed the half-sovereign to Cannon—he passed it on to the desk again, and said he would rather have silver—I took the half-sovereign from him, and gave him silver—I believed it to be the same I gave him—I put it back to the desk without examining it—it was done in an instant—it was put back into the bowl where the gold was—there was no other half-sovereign there—they then left the shop—soon after the policeman came—I gave the half-sovereign to Morris—he marked it, and handed it to Goff.

Cross-examined. Q. Have you a distinct recollection of weighing this half-sovereign? A. I received it from Morris, and weighed it—it was the only one I had received that morning—I weighed it by a pair of scales and a stamped weight—I did not examine the bowl at the time I put it in, but I did a few minutes before, when I turned over the gold, there were but two or three sovereigns in the bowl.
MR. CHAMBERS. Q. Do you know when this half-sovereign was taken? A. About twelve o'clock—there were no others put in the bowl.
WILLIAM MORRIS . I am assistant to Mr. Dixon, in Blackfriars-road. I received a half-sovereign from Mr. Greaves, and marked it—I handed the same to Gough.
Cross-examined. Q. What mark did you put on it? A. A cross on the neck, with a pair of scissors.

BENJAMIN LOCK WOOD . I am assistant to Mr. Bayfield, a pawnbroker, in the New-cut. In coming from Kennington-cross to the Blackfriars-road you can come through the New-cut—on the 22nd of May, Garrard came to me for a sovereign for a pound's worth of silver—I did not see any on else with him.

GEORGE LANGRIDGE , assistant to a pawnbroker, Waterloo-road. On the 22nd of May, Cannon came and asked for a sovereign for a pound's worth of silver—I gave him a new sovereign—he asked me to give him one of that reign.

ESTHER CLARK . On the 22nd of May, I was in the service of a stay
maker, in Westminster-road. Cannon came and asked for change for a sove
reign, and handed me a new sovereign—I had not got it, and I sent Sarah Jenkins out—she returned with four half-crowns and a half-sovereign change, and handed it to Cannon—he said, "Thank you," and went to the door, and said, "Here, John, is the half-sovereign I owe yon;" and then I saw Garrard—he said, "I should like silver;" and Cannon said, "Perhaps this young person will give you change for the half-sovereign"—I looked for some silver, and gave it to Cannon—he passed me over a half-sovereign—I put it into the till—there was no other half-sovereign there—I am sure of that—they thanked me, and went out—the policeman came in immediately after—I then gave him the half-sovereign I had received from Cannon.

Cross-examined. Q. Had you ever seen either of the prisoners before? A. No—I had examined the till before I put the half-sovereign in—Mr. Cox took the cash away the night before, and we had not received a half-sovereign in the course of that day.
SARAH JENKINS . I was sent for change for a sovereign by Clark—I went to a pawnbroker's, and gave the change to Cannon.

WILLIAM THOMAS WEELANDS , pawnbroker, Lambeth. On the 22nd of May, Jenkins came to my shop for change for a sovereign—she asked me to give her a half-sovereign, and the rest in silver—it was a good half-sovereign—we always sound our money on the counter.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you speak to any distinct recollection of having sounded this one, or only your general practice? A. From a recollection of having sounded this one, I know, because Jenkins came in about half an hour after, and asked if I had given her a good half-sovereign—a bad half-sovereign will ring, but not like a good one.

JAMES BROOK (police-constable L 118.) I was with Goff in the Lambeth-road, between twelve and one o'clock, on the 22nd of May—I saw the two prisoners in conversation together, and followed them to see where they went to—Cannon went into a tobacconist's shop of the name of Compton—they joined company again, and went to Mr. Hildyard's—I remained outside watch
ing—after they came from there I followed them again—I went into Mr. Hill's, came out, and pursued them again—I next saw them in the Kenning
ton-road—they both went into the Duke of Clarence, near the Obelisk, re
mained there ten minutes or a quarter of an hour, then came out together, and went up the Blackfriars-road, and both went into Mr. Dixon's—Goff went into Dixon's, and I went after the prisoners—they both went into Bayfield's shop—after that they went into a beer-shop in the Waterloo-road, and staid there a short time—after that Cannon went into a pawnbroker's in the Waterloo-road, and then proceeded to the Dover Castle wine-vaults, and stayed there a little while, then into an oil-shop, and then to Cox's—after they came out I went into Mr. Cox—I followed them, and took them both—on searching them I found four half-crowns on each—I received this half-sovereign from Esther Clark, and this one from Miss Hildyard.

Cross-examined. Q. Where have you kept the half-sovereigns? A. Locked up in my desk at home—I have always kept the key—I do not know that I was in a public-house with any of the witnesses just before the examination—I was not tossing for beer with any of them—I do not recollect having beer with any of them—I did not say, "Here, drink, for we shall be better up to our mark"—I recollect being with some of them after the exa
mination—I was drinking with Mr. Morris and Mr. Weelands, at the Catherine Wheel after the examination—I swear it was after that.

CHARLES BURGESS GOFF (police-constable L 83.) I produce a half-sove
reign, which I got from Morris—I was with Brook on the 22nd of May—I saw the two prisoners in conversation together—I was with Brook when he followed them.

Cross-examined. Q. Were you at a public-house drinking with any of the witnesses on the day of the examination? A. I think I was—I think it was after the examination—I am not sure—I did not hear anything said about drink, and we shall be better up to our mark—there was no tossing to my knowledge.

MR. JOHN FIELD . I am inspector of coin to the Mint. These three half-sovereigns are all counterfeit, and all cast in one mould—they are of white metal, and have been gilt to represent a half-sovereign, by a new process of voltaic electricity—they will not ring like genuine half-sovereigns—two of them are very much lighter than a genuine half-sovereign—they will be easily detected, by trying them on the finger, without the assistance of scales.

CANNON—
GUILTY . Aged 23.

GARRARD—
GUILTY . Aged 16.

1799.
JOHN RUSSELL , was indicted
for unlawfully uttering counter
feit coin.

JAMES TAYLOR . I keep a shop. On the 4th of June, the prisoner came to my shop for half a pint of porter—he gave me a good half-crown, and I gave him 2s. 6d. change—I observed a cross on the head of each shilling—he took them off the counter, and the halfpence also, and said, "Master, you have given me a dark one," and gave me back 1s., which I saw was a bad one and had no cross on it—I took it and beckoned to a person to stop him—I gave the shilling to West, the officer.
THOMAS WEST (police-constable M 249.) I received this shilling from Taylor.
MR. JOHN FIELD . This is a counterfeit shilling.

Prisoner's Defence. He said he could not give me change, and then he found the shillings; as soon as he put them down I said this one looks rather dark; he took it up and went into the tap-room, and out came three men, who said it was a good one.

JAMES TAYLOR
re-examined. About five minutes elapsed from the time of his passing the bad shilling and his being searched—there were two more behind him, near enough to touch him—I marked the shillings, because it was the fourth time I had been served so.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Six Months.

1800.
ALEXANDER REVELL was indicted
for stealing 1 watch-guard, value 1s.; 1 cross, 1s.; 2 keys, 6d.; 1 reticule, 1s.; 2 half-crowns, 2 shil
lings, 2 sixpences, 3 pence, and 4 halfpence, the property of
Sarah Shirley; from her person.

SARAH SHIRLEY . I am servant to Mr. Maldon, in the City-road. I was returning down the Kent-road, about ten o'clock at night, on the 28th of May—there were three boys together—one of them made up to me, and took my reticule from my arm—it contained the property stated—this is it—I I do not know who the person was—he ran down a street.

JOSEPH SKINNER . I live at Peckham. I heard a cry of "Stop thief," and saw the prisoner running, and saw him throw this bag down—I took it up with my right hand, and took him with my left—this is the bag.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. What are you? A. An auc
tioneer and appraiser—I have no doubt about the prisoner.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Three Months.

1801.
GEORGE WESTCOTT was indicted
for embezzlement.
CATHARINE SOAMES . I am a widow, and live in Dorset-street, Clapham-road. On the 5th of May I paid the prisoner 7s. 7d. for his master, Mr. Fox, for beer, and on the 7th of June 11s. 1d.
MARY ANN ROWCLIFFE . I paid the prisoner 2s. 3d. on the 2nd of June for his master.

CHARLES FOX . The prisoner was my servant—if he received money, it was his duty to pay it to me directly—if he received 7s. 7d. he has not paid it to me at any time—if he received 2s. 3d. from Mrs. Rowcliffe he has not paid me, nor 11s. 1d. from Soames—he has paid 10s. on account of what he has had from me.

JOHN MENNIE (police-constable V 70.) I took the prisoner, and found on him seven bills, which his master had given him to give to customers, but he kept them back, and has eceived the monies weekly from the customers.
Prisoner's Defence. I acknowledge receiving the money; I paid him 10s. of it, and promised the rest in a week.

GUILTY .—
Confined Three Months.

1802.
JOHN ABRAHAM was indicted
for assaulting
Ann Baker, with intent, &c.
NOT GUILTY .
Page 213, line 13, for "said take it off," read, "did take it off."
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, THE 1ST OF JULY.
